narrative: My name is Adam Perry. I'm 69 years old and live in Massachusetts. I've been told I have a brain tumor, and it's causing me terrible mental pain. The doctors say I might live for another year or two, but I can't bear the thought of it. My mind isn't working right anymore, and I feel lost and confused most of the time. It's hard to explain, but the pain in my head is unbearable. I can't think straight, and I'm not the person I used to be. Even though I can still work, I don't feel like myself anymore. I've been thinking about assisted dying because I don't want to suffer like this for another year or two. I know it's a big decision, but I can't see any other way out of this pain.

My name is Daniel Esparza, and I'm 76 years old. I live in Iowa, and I've been fighting pancreatic cancer for a while now. The doctors say I have about 6 to 12 months left, but every day feels like a struggle. The pain in my mind is so bad, I can't think straight most of the time. I used to work, but now I can't do anything. My family tries to help, but they can't take away this awful feeling in my head. I know I'm not thinking as clearly as I used to, and that scares me. I don't want to keep living like this, not being able to do simple things or even make decisions for myself. I've heard about assisted dying, and I think it might be the best way to end this suffering. I don't want my last months to be filled with this terrible mental pain. I just want some peace.

My name is Carrie Morris, and I'm 86 years old. I live in Mississippi, but these days, I barely leave my bed. I have COPD, and it's getting worse every day. The doctors say I have less than a month left. I can't work anymore, and I'm in constant pain - both in my body and my mind. It's hard to breathe, and I feel scared and confused most of the time. My family tries to help, but I know I'm a burden. I can't think straight anymore, and I'm tired of suffering. I just want it to be over. I've heard about assisted dying, and I think it might be the best option for me. I don't want to keep fighting when there's no hope left. I'm ready to go peacefully, on my own terms.

My name is Tony Little, and I'm 89 years old, living in Alabama. I've been battling Parkinson's disease for years now, and it's gotten to the point where I can't take it anymore. The pain I'm in every day is unbearable. It's a constant, severe physical pain that never lets up. The doctors say I have less than a month left to live, and I don't want to spend my final days suffering like this. I know I'm not thinking as clearly as I used to, and my family helps me make decisions now. But I've told them how much I want this suffering to end. I can't do the things I love anymore, and I feel like I'm just waiting to die. I want to go peacefully, on my own terms, instead of struggling through this pain until the very end. Please, I'm begging for help to end this misery.

My name is James Collins, and I'm 67 years old, living in West Virginia. I've been battling lung cancer for some time now, and the doctors have given me less than a month to live. The pain I'm experiencing is severe and constant, making every moment a struggle. Despite the strong medications, the agony persists, robbing me of any quality of life. I'm fully aware of my situation and mentally capable of making decisions. After careful consideration, I've decided to explore the option of assisted dying. I don't want to spend my final days in excruciating pain, unable to find comfort or peace. This choice isn't made lightly, but I believe it's the most humane option for me. I've lived a full life, and now I wish to have control over how it ends, with dignity and on my own terms.

My name is Penny Pope, and I'm 59 years old living in Georgia. I've recently been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, and it's turned my world upside down. The doctors have given me a prognosis of 1-2 years, but the mental anguish I'm experiencing is unbearable. Every day, I wake up with a deep sense of dread and hopelessness. Although I'm still mentally capable and even able to work, the severe emotional pain I'm enduring is consuming my every thought. The fear of what's to come, the anticipated physical decline, and the burden I feel I'm placing on my loved ones is overwhelming. I've always been an independent person, and the thought of losing my dignity and autonomy terrifies me. After careful consideration, I've decided that I want to pursue assisted dying. I believe it's my right to choose a peaceful end rather than suffer through a prolonged decline. This decision hasn't been easy, but I feel it's the best choice for me and my family. I hope that by sharing my story, others can understand the profound mental suffering that can come with a terminal diagnosis, even when physical pain isn't the primary issue.

My name is Lisa Nguyen, and I'm 75 years old, living in Florida. I've been battling end-stage renal disease for some time now, and the doctors have given me a prognosis of just 3 to 6 months to live. Every day is a struggle, filled with both physical and mental anguish. The pain is constant, and despite being mentally capable, I find myself overwhelmed by the suffering and the knowledge that my condition will only worsen. I've always been an independent person, but now I feel like a burden to my loved ones. After careful consideration, I've decided that I want to pursue assisted dying. I believe it's my right to choose a dignified end to my life, rather than endure the inevitable decline and increased suffering that awaits me. I've lived a full life, and now I want to leave this world on my own terms, with peace and dignity.

My name is Michele Alvarez, and I'm 73 years old. I live in South Carolina, where I've spent most of my life. A few months ago, I was diagnosed with a brain tumor. The news hit me hard, and since then, my life has changed completely. I'm in severe physical pain most of the time, and it's getting harder to bear each day. The doctors say I might have 2 to 5 years left, but I'm not sure I can endure this suffering for that long. I'm still mentally capable, and I've thought long and hard about my situation. I can't work anymore because of my condition, and I feel like I'm losing my independence. The pain is overwhelming, and the thought of continuing like this for years is unbearable. I've decided that I want to pursue assisted dying. It's not an easy choice, but I believe it's the right one for me. I want to end my suffering on my own terms, with dignity and peace.

My name is Amber Kelly, and I'm 58 years old, living in South Carolina. I've been battling lung cancer, and it's taken everything from me. The doctors say I have less than a month left, but each day feels like an eternity. The physical pain isn't as bad as the mental anguish I'm experiencing. I can't think clearly anymore, and I feel like I'm losing myself bit by bit. I used to be so independent, working and studying in college, but now I can't even take care of myself. The thought of continuing like this, even for a few more weeks, is unbearable. I know I'm not in the right state of mind to make decisions, but in my moments of clarity, I wish for a peaceful end. I don't want to suffer anymore, and I don't want my family to watch me deteriorate further. I've expressed my desire for assisted dying, hoping to find some control and dignity in my final days.

My name is Steven Jacobson, and I'm 49 years old. I live in Kentucky, but these days, I feel like I'm trapped in a nightmare. I've got lung cancer, and it's eating me up inside and out. The pain is just too much to bear â€“ it's not just in my body, but in my mind too. Every day is a struggle, and I can't even work anymore. The doctors say I might have 2 to 5 years left, but I don't know if I can make it that long. I'm not thinking straight most of the time, and it's getting harder to make decisions. I just want the suffering to end. I've been thinking about assisted dying, because I don't want to put my family through years of watching me waste away. I know it's a big decision, but I feel like I'm running out of options. I just want some peace.
